content: The "Governors Island Preservation Act of 2000" is enacted by the United States Congress. It is also known as the "Governors Island Preservation Act of 2000". The "Governors Island Preservation Act of 2000" was enacted by Congress to preserve the historical significance of Governors Island, which played a crucial role in defending the United States during various conflicts, including the Battle of Long Island and the War of 1812. The excavation of the Lexington Avenue Subway in Manhattan increased Governors Island from 90 to 172 acres. It played a significant role in the Civil War, World War I, and World War II, serving the United States Army until 1966. In 1966, the Army relocated, and the United States Coast Guard took over, contributing to the Coast Guard's efforts on the Atlantic coast for 30 years. The Coast Guard ceased operations at Governors Island in 1997, leaving 225 buildings unoccupied and exposed to the elements. Castle Williams is named after Lieutenant Colonel Jonathan Williams, who built the fort. Fort Jay, named after John Jay, complements Fort Wood on nearby Bedloe Island. Castle Williams and Fort Jay, part of the Governors Island National Historic Landmark District, are crucial to US history and should be protected as a unit of the National Park System. The State of New York and the city of New York have agreed on a redevelopment plan for Governors Island. The Development Corporation offers the opportunity to ensure public access to Governors Island, preserve historic structures, involve local officials and organizations in redevelopment, and provide educational and recreational facilities. The Act aims to prevent deterioration of historic military buildings on Governors Island in New York Harbor. The Act aims to preserve Castle Williams and Fort Jay on Governors Island in New York Harbor for the benefit of the people of the United States. It also provides public access to the island, open park space with views of New York Harbor, and opportunities to learn about the island's historical significance. Additionally, it aims to return property to the State of New York that was previously conveyed to the Federal government. The State of New York conveyed property to the Federal Government for defense purposes. The definitions in this Act include terms like Administrator, City, Corporation, Management plan, Monument, Secretary, and State. The Act also establishes the Governors Island National Monument. Establishment of the Governors Island National Monument in New York Harbor includes historic structures like Castle Williams and Fort Jay. The Monument comprises the land where these structures are located, as depicted on a specific map. The map of the Governors Island National Monument is available for public inspection at National Park Service offices. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, administrative jurisdiction over the Monument will be transferred to the Secretary. The Administrator will reserve access rights for the Secretary to operate and maintain the Monument, including utilities provision. The Monument's determination and administration will be part of the Governors Island disposition process and subject to agreement between the Secretary and the Corporation. Upon transfer, the Secretary will administer the Monument in accordance with this Act and National Park System laws. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements with interested entities for the preservation, development, and use of the Monument. A management plan must be prepared within 2 years of the Act's enactment in consultation with the Corporation and other entities. The Secretary is required to prepare a management plan for the Monument in accordance with applicable laws and submit it to the relevant committees in Congress upon completion. Authorization of Appropriations for the annual operation and maintenance of the Monument is authorized by the Senate. SEC. 5. CONVEYANCE OF GOVERNORS ISLAND. The Administrator shall convey all right, title, and interest of the United States in Governors Island to the State of New York for no consideration, excluding the Monument, to be administered by the Corporation. Upon conveyance of Governors Island to the State of New York, the use of the land must comply with environmental laws and preservation guidelines outlined in the Governors Island Preservation and Design Manual approved by the Administrator, State, and City.
